awd_titl_txt: Facilitating Accessibility in STEM at Two-Year Colleges
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by providing science and math faculty with practical skills to teach students with disabilities at two-year colleges. A greater proportion of the student population at two-year colleges have documented disabilities compared with four-year institutions. To improve inclusivity and diversity in STEM, it is important that students with disabilities achieve success at rates comparable to the whole population. While reasonable accommodations are provided for each student, more nuanced techniques will enhance the student experience, provide more opportunities for success, and give guidance to faculty. This training conference will bring expertise to science and math faculty at two-year colleges, engaging them in specific, practical, and immediately implementable skills to better engage with neurodivergent students, and students with visual, auditory, or mobility disabilities. Conference participants will learn techniques, initiate a community of practice to support each other, and become faculty liaisons within their own institutions and regional groups.

The overall goal of this project is to convene a conference that prepares two-year college faculty to support students with disabilities. Participants in the conference will include two-year college faculty in math, physics, and chemistry. The conference will offer workshops to help faculty enhance student graphical literacy among students with visual disabilities, and to ensure laboratory safety for students with mobility disabilities. Participants will gain first-hand knowledge of accessibility challenges through a student-led science museum tour and a panel discussion. Disciplinary and cross disciplinary discussions will support the creation of communication channels to brainstorm specific strategies for inclusive teaching while providing opportunities for participants to develop and facilitate similar workshops in their home institutions. The conference will be organized by the leaders of three two-year college professional organizations and convened in Minneapolis, Minnesota with expected attendance of 24 participants. Dissemination will involve multiple modalities, including presentations at conferences, professional disciplinary societies and a handbook of helpful practices will be widely distributed. The NSF program description on Advancing Innovation and Impact in Undergraduate STEM Education at Two-year Institutions of Higher Education supports projects that advance STEM education initiatives at two-year colleges. The program description promotes innovative and evidence-based practices in undergraduate STEM education at two-year colleges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Facilitating Accessibility in STEM at Two-Year Colleges conference was held in collaboration with the American Mathematical Association of Two-Year Colleges (AMATYC), the Organization for Physics at Two-Year Colleges (OPTYCs), and the Two-Year College Chemistry Consortium (2YC3). The primary goals of the conference were to improve awareness and exchange of best practices for inclusive and accessible teaching and learning in quantitative heavy disciplines, identify opportunities and structures within professional societies that can be leveraged in growing a community of practice for two-year college STEM faculty, and provide opportunities for participants to propagate knowledge gained through participation in the conference through their professional societies and their institutions.

As STEM fields aim to increase access and improve retention of students, there is a need for improved inclusion of students with disabilities. Two-year colleges (TYCs) have a larger proportion of students with documented disabilities which means that TYC STEM instructors need to be better equipped to support students with disabilities. The presentations and activities provided during the conference were selected to provide faculty with knowledge and tools that can be implemented in supporting students with disabilities. Presentations and workshops offered were:

  • Keynote presentation focused on the Universal Design for Learning Framework. 
  • Workshop focused on teaching neurodiverse students in biology, chemistry, and mathematics settings. 
  • Presentation about designing accessible materials.
  • Campus tours led by students of Minneapolis Community and Technical College focused on the student’s experiences in their STEM courses, including a question-and-answer period with each student.
  • Workshop focused on translating visual representations of STEM concepts into resources that could help students with low or no vision. This was in the context of geosciences, but many resources were applicable to math and physics.
  • Presentation about meeting the needs of students who are deaf or hard of hearing.

In Fall 2023, we hosted two follow-up workshops to discuss with participants how to sustain a community of practice in support of teaching students with disabilities. Through these workshops we have raised awareness of the needs of students with disabilities and how these students are assets in the college classroom. In addition, participants have disseminated the knowledge shared at the workshop through presentations at their own campuses and regional conferences. One group of participants has submitted an additional grant proposal to the NSF to build upon this work initiated by this conference. To share insights more broadly about teaching students with disabilities, the presenters and facilitators from the workshop are contributing examples of practical ways to support students with disabilities; these vignettes will be part of a white paper that will be published in 2024.
